description: From Middle English *give, *gyve (found only in plural gives, gyves (“shackles; fetters”)). Of uncertain origin. Compare Welsh gefyn (“fetter, shackle”), Irish geibbionn (“fetters”), geimheal (“fetter, chain, shackle”). The modern pronunciation with /dʒ/ is due to the spelling.
The verb is from Middle English given, gyven (“to shackle”), from the noun.

entries.meaning: (literary) A shackle or fetter, especially for the leg.
examples: With head and heart and hand I’ll strive
To break the rod, and rend the gyve,—
The spoiler of his prey deprive,—

verbs.description: gyve (third-person singular simple present gyves, present participle gyving, simple past and past participle gyved)
